messageBody:
Michael Schuerig wrote:

>I'm using (easy)mocks most of the time, too. Now I'm in a situation
>where I want to ensure that multiple DB operations (selects, create
>temp tables, inserts, ...) happen in the same transaction, as only then
>the code works properly. Are you using mocks in cases like this? How?
>
>
>
Hmm... I've never used mocks this way, but my ideas would be: at JDBC
level, you can always use con.setAutoCommit(false) (con being a
Connection object) to start a transaction... and con.commit() and
con.setAutoCommit(true) to get transaction semantics.

To use the same in mock, maybe you can put each of the database
operations in a separate method in a plain java bean, and start calling
those methods like (which is also called 'recording' in mock parlance):

mock.insertEmployee(...);
mock.updateDepartment(...);

And so on. Once you call control.replay() and call the business method
which calls all the above data access/modifying methods, and finally end
it with control.verify(), easyMock automatically checks whether all the
methods have been called or not. Does this solution give the transaction
semantics that you are expecting?

Vamsee.
